If attribute x is under-estimated or well-estimated, the average of its real values is lower than or equal to the average of its subjective values. Then, based on the Fechner law, the following relationship holds:
div.formula: 1 N ∑ i∈N κ x log(x i ) ≤x (21)
div.p: where N is the number of samples of attribute x. Eq. 21 implies that:
div.formula: κ x ≤ ∑ i∈N x i ∑ i∈N log(x i ) ≤ 1(22)
div.p: Since attributes x and y are of the same modality, κ x = κ y = κ. From Eq. 22, κ y = κ ≤ 1 and then, the following inequality holds:
div.formula: 1 N ∑ i∈N κ y log(y i ) ≤ 1 N ∑ i∈N κ y y i =ȳ(23)
div.p: Eq. 23 contradicts the statement that attribute y is overestimated. Therefore, the initial statement has been proven. P 2A . Consider an attribute x that is under-estimated or wellestimated. If the exponent α x in Stevens' power law function associated with x is greater or equal than 1, α x will be upper bounded by 1 − log(κ x )/ log(x).
Proof. Without loss of generality, consider a set of N samples of the attribute x. If attribute x is underestimated or well-estimated, the following inequality holds:
div.formula: 1 N ∑ i∈N κ x x α i ≤ 1 N ∑ i∈N x i =x(24)
div.p: If the exponent α x is greater than 1, the function κx α x i is convex. Then, the LHS can be lower bounded using Jensen's inequality for convex functions (Jensen, 1906) :
div.formula: κ xx α ≤ 1 n ∑ i∈N κx α x i ≤x α x ≤ 1 − log(κ x ) log(x)(25)
P 2B .
div.p: Consider an attribute y that is overestimated or wellestimated. If the exponent α y of Stevens' power law function associated with y is lower or equal than 1, α y is lower bounded by 1 − log(κ y )/ log(ȳ)
Proof. Without loss of generality, consider a set of N y samples of attribute y. If attribute y is overestimated (Eq. 47) or well-estimated (Eq. 46) , the following two inequalities hold:
div.formula: 1 N ∑ i∈N κ y y α y i ≥ 1 N ∑ i∈N y i =ȳ 1 N ∑ i∈N −y α y i ≤ −ȳ κ y(26)
div.p: If α y ≤ 1, the function −y α y i is convex. Then, the LHS of Eq. 26 can be lower bounded using Jensen's inequality for convex functions :
div.formula: −ȳ α y ≤ 1 N y ∑ i∈N −y α y i ≤ −ȳ κ y α y ≥ 1 − log(κ y ) log(ȳ)(27)
P 2C .
div.p: Consider an attribute x that is well-estimated and another attribute y that is over-estimated. If the exponent α x of Stevens' power law function associated with attribute x is equal to 1, the exponent α y of attribute y is greater than 1

Proof. Note first that if α x = 1, then κ = 1, which follows directly from combining the results obtained in propositions P 2A and P 2B . If attribute x is well-estimated and its exponent is equal to 1, α x is lower and upper bounded by the same quantity:
div.formula: 1 − log(κ x ) log(x) ≤α x ≤ 1 − log(κ x ) log(x) → α x = 1 − log(0) log(x) = 1(28)
div.p: If the two attributes are in the same modality, then κ x = κ y = 1. If attribute y is overestimated:
div.formula: 1 N ∑ i∈N y α y i > 1 N ∑ i∈N y i =ȳ (29)
div.p: This inequality only holds if α y > 1, which implies that α y > α x = 1. P 2D . Consider two attributes x and y in the same modality but elicited with stimuli of different intensities. Suppose that x is well estimated and y is overestimated. Assume that the stimulus' values of y are strictly greater than those for x. Then, if both attributes are in the same modality, the exponent of the psychophysical function is greater for attribute y than for attribute x
Proof. If the attributes are in the same modality, κ x = κ y = κ. If attribute y is overestimated by ∆ > 0:
div.formula: 1 N ∑ i∈N κy α y i =ȳ + ∆ (30) If attribute x is well-estimated 1 N ∑ i∈N κx α x i = 1 N ∑ i∈N x i =x(31)
div.p: Without loss of generality, define the following relationship between the attribute values y i = x i + δ i , which implies thatx =ȳ −δ whereδ is the average of the difference of the attributes. Since y is strictly greater than x, δ i > 0, ∀i ∈ N and thus,δ > 0 andȳ >x. Then equating Eq. 30 and 31:
div.formula: 1 N ∑ i∈N κy α x i − ∆ = 1 N ∑ i∈N κ(x i ) α x +δ 1 N ∑ i∈N κy α y i − 1 N ∑ i∈N κ(x i + δ i ) α x = ∆ +δ ∑ i∈N y α y i − ∑ i∈N (y i + δ i ) α x = N(∆ +δ) κ ≥ 0 → ∑ i∈N y α y i ≥ ∑ i∈N (y i + δ i ) α x (32)
div.p: Since δ i > 0, ∀i ∈ N, the inequality holds only if α y > α x .
div.formula: P 3A .
div.p: Consider two attributes x and y. Assume that their scale constants are equal and that their values are similar. Suppose that it is wrongly assumed that the exponents of their psychophysical functions are the same. Then, the higher the difference in the exponents of attributes y and x, the lower the marginal rate of substitution of attribute x for attribute y

Proof. Let's define ρ xy = θ x /θ y as the true marginal rate of substitution andθ x andθ y as the estimated parameters of Stevens' power function when both exponents are wrongly assumed to be equal to α x = α y =ᾱ. Consider a pair of values x i , y i ∀i ∈ N and equate the systematic utilities obtained from the true and estimated model:
div.formula: θ x κ x x i α x + θ y κ y y i α y =θ x xᾱ i +θ y yᾱ i (33)
div.p: Then, let's write the value of the biased parametersθ x andθ y as a function of the value of the true parameters:
div.formula: θ x = θ x κ x x i α x −ᾱ ,θ y = θ y κ y y i α y −ᾱ(34)
div.p: Then, the estimated marginal rate of substitutionρ xy becomes equal to:
div.formula: ρ xy =θ x θ y = θ x κ x x α x −ᾱ i θ y κ y y α y −ᾱ i = ρ xy κ x κ y x α x y α y i yᾱ i xᾱ i(35)
div.p: Let's use the assumption that scale constants are equal and that both attributes' values are similar (x i ≈ y i ≈ t):
div.formula: ρ xy = ρ xy t α x −α y = ρ xy t α y −α x = ρ xy t ∆α(36)
div.p: where ∆α = α y − α x is the difference between the exponents of y and x. Then, it suffices that the values of x and y are positive to prove that as ∆α is higher, the value of ρ xy is lower. P 3B . Consider two attributes x and y. Assume that their scale constants are equal and that their values are similar. Then, if the exponents of the psychophysical function of attributes y and x are equal to an arbitrary value, the estimated and true marginal rate of substitution of attribute x with respect to y are the same Proof. This proposition follows directly from Eq. 36 in proposition P 3A and the fact that α x = α y = α:
div.formula: ρ xy = ρ xy t α−α = ρ xy(37)
div.p: Appendix C Assumptions

Assumptions are divided into three groups. Global assumptions apply to data gathered across all experimental conditions. The group of assumptions A N and A A apply to choice data gathered from the numerical and animated conditions, respectively.

div.head: C.1 Notation
div.p: Below is the notation used for this section. Supraindices refer to the experimental condition and subindices to the characteristics of individual n ∈ N, its city of origin g ∈ {s, l} and type of attribute k ∈ {w, v}. If choices from two experimental conditions or decision scenarios are made by the same participant, it is reasonable to expect that their preference weights will be the same. For a similar argument, the time perception function and the scale of the random errors can be also assumed to be homogeneous for a set of choices made by the same participant. In the context of our experiment, this means that parameters become no longer indexed by within-participants condition y:
div.formula: λ z ngk = λ az ngk = λ nz ngk , β z ngk = β az ngk = β nz ngk , α z ngk = α az ngk = α nz ngk , κ z ngk = κ az ngk = κ nz ngk ∀z = {c, t}, g = {s, l}, k = {w, v}, n ∈ N(38)
div.p: A 2 . Homogeneity of preferences weights, scale of random errors, and parameters of the perception function from individuals drawn from the same city.

Assuming homogeneity in individuals' preferences on choice data gathered from the same experiment is a standard practice in discrete choice analysis 12 . Formally,this 12 This assumption is stronger than A 1 but it can be relaxed with dis-means that parameters become no longer indexed by the individual n but only for the type of time attribute k and the individuals' city of origin c:
div.formula: λ yz gk = λ yc ngk , β yz gk = β yc ngk , α yz gk = α yc ngk , κ yz gk = κ yc ngk , ∀y = {a, n}, z = {c, t}, g = {s, l}, k = {w, v}, n ∈ N (39)
div.p: A 3 . Homogeneity of scale constant of the perception function for attributes elicited with a stimulus of the same modality.

The scale constant in psychophysical functions depends only on the scale unit and modality of the stimuli. Then, it is safe to assume that the scale constant will be the same within an experimental condition, regardless of the type of time attribute. Formally, this means that the scale constant κ becomes no longer indexed by the type of attribute k in both animated and numerical choices:
div.formula: κ yz ng = κ yz ngw = κ yz ngv , ∀y ∈ {a, n}, z ∈ {c, t}, c ∈ {s, l}, n ∈ N(40)
div.p: A 4 . Homogeneity of exponents in the perception function for attributes elicited with stimuli of same modality and intensity.

The first implication of this assumption is that the exponents of waiting and in-vehicle times are the same in the numerical condition (Eq. 41). The second implication is that the exponent for the in-vehicle time in the animated condition is the same regardless of the withinparticipants condition (Eq. 42) 13 . Formally:
div.formula: α n ng = α nc ngk = α nt ngk , ∀ c ∈ {s, l}, k = {w, v}, n ∈ N (41) α a ngv = α ac ngv = α at ngv , ∀g ∈ {s, l}, n ∈ N(42)

div.head: C.3 Numeric choices (A N1 ,A N2 )
div.p: A N1 . Homogeneity of preferences weights, scale of random errors and parameters of the perception function The validity of this assumption follows from the correctness of the randomization of participants between experimental conditions. Formally, this means that parameters in the numerical condition become no longer indexed by between-participants condition y in the numerical choices:
div.formula: λ n gk = λ nc ngk = λ nt ngk , β n gk = β nc ngk = β nt ngk , α n gk = α nc ngk = α nt ngk , κ n gk = κ nc ngk = κ nt ngk , ∀y = {a, n}, z = {c, t}, g = {s, l}, k = {w, v}, n ∈ N (43)

div.head: C.4 Animated choices (A A1 ,A A2 ,A A3 ,A A4 )
div.p: A A1 . Duration information time does not influence estimation of waiting times crete choice models that allow for heterogeneity in taste variation. This is left for further research but the reader may be interested in reviewing the mixed logit model (Train, 2009) 13 The stimuli used to elicit in-vehicle time in the between-participants condition in the animated choices was not manipulated

This assumption implies that both the scale constants and the exponents of the psychophysical function of waiting times in the animated choices are the same regardless of the between-participants condition. The validity of this assumption is supported by the analysis of the time estimation responses which shows no difference in the average waiting time estimates' between experimental conditions. Formally:
div.formula: α a ngw = α ac ngw = α at ngw , ∀g ∈ {s, l}, n ∈ N(44)
div.p: A A2 . The impact of duration information time on utility attained by an alternative is proportional to the amount of perceived waiting in that alternative Previous studies show that duration information has a negative effect on consumer satisfaction (Hui and Zhou, 1996;Pruyn and Smidts, 1998) and that its impact on consumer evaluation is proportional to the amount of perceived waiting time (Antonides et al., 2006). If the assumption holds, the following relationship between the marginal utility of perceived waiting times in each within-subject condition can be derived:
div.formula: ∂V ∂Ψ at ngw = τ • ∂V ∂Ψ ac ngw → θ at ngw = τ θ ac ngw (45)
div.p: where τ is an arbitrary constant greater than 0 that quantifies the difference in the marginal utility of perceived waiting time when duration information is or is not revealed. τ = 1 suggests that duration information has no impact on utility.

div.head: A A3 . Waiting times are well estimated
div.p: This assumption follows from the analysis of the waiting time estimation responses. We assume that participants provide an average estimate of the waiting time from all routes experienced during the decision scenarios. Formally:
div.formula: 1 2|S| ∑ s∈S ∑ i∈A ns κ ngw w α ngw i = 1 2|S| ∑ s∈S ∑ i∈A ns w i =w (46)
div.p: A A4 . In-vehicle times are overestimated Using the same arguments given to support assumption A 8 but noting that in-vehicle times are overestimated, we have the following condition:
div.formula: 1 2|S| ∑ s∈S ∑ i∈A ns κ ngw w α ngv i > 1 2|S| ∑ s∈S ∑ i∈A ns v i =v (47) Appendix D Model Fitting D.1 Maximum likelihood estimation (MLE)
div.p: The parameters of the discrete choice model can be obtained via MLE. This can be cast as the following unconstrained optimization problem:
div.formula: maximize θ ink ∏ n∈N ∏ i∈A n P y ni ni (θ nik )(48)
div.p: where
div.formula: P nik (θ nik ) = exp(λV ni (θ nik )) ∑ j∈A n exp(λV nj (θ njk )) V ni (θ nik ) = ∑ k∈K i θ nik Ψ nik (x nik ) ∀i ∈ A i ∀n ∈ N y ni = I(individual n chooses alternative i)
div.p: Because the logarithm is a monotonic transformation, maximizing the log-likelihood gives the MLE estimates and thus, the optimization problem is equivalent to:
div.formula: ℓ(θ) = ∑ n∈N ∑ i∈A n y ni log(P ni (θ nik )) = ∑ n∈N ∑ i∈A n y ni λV nj (θ njk ) − ln ∑ j∈A n exp(λV nj (θ njk )) (49)
div.p: The MLE estimators are obtained as:
div.formula: θ θ θ ⋆ = arg max θ θ θ ℓ(θ θ θ)(50)

div.head: D.2 Local optima
div.p: If the observable part of the utility function V is linear in parameters, the likelihood function ℓ can be proven to be globally concave, and thus, the optimal solution for θ θ θ is unique (Train, 2009). However, if the time perception function Ψ nik is consistent with Steven's law, an exponential parameter is introduced in V, and hence the global concavity of ℓ cannot be guaranteed. In this setting, an optimization of the likelihood function can lead to local optima and it can be highly sensitive to the starting points for the optimization. Therefore, non-convex optimization problems are hard to solve and there are only guarantees of convergence toward local optima.

div.head: D.3 Optimization algorithm
div.p: Grid search is a gradient-free optimization method that can be useful to deal with low-dimensional non-convex objectives. The quality of the solution and performance obtained by a grid search directly depends on the size and dimension of the feasible space. This consideration is key as the solution to a problem with a grid search could become intractable with the curse of dimensionality. In our problem, the parameter search can be easily narrowed by leveraging the concavity of the likelihood function once the vector of exponential parameters of the time perception functions α α α is known. Therefore, this equates to conducting a grid search on α α α and then solving a convex optimization for the linear parameters of the utility function.

As shown in algorithm 1, the Cartesian product given by α α α 1 × . . . × α α α D makes the computational complexity to growth exponentially with the dimension D of the vector of exponential parameters (O(T D )). The level of granularity to search the feasible space is moderated by T and it should be set according to the computational resources.

To reduce the computational burden in problems with a large number of exponential parameters, it is recommended a random search over an arbitrary range of values for the parameters. Random search has been used extensively in the machine learning community in the context of hyper-parameter optimization and it has been shown to exhibit better performance than a deterministic grid search in high dimensional spaces (Bergstra and Bengio, 2012). The choice of bounds α α α min , α α α max for the range of values of the grid search conducted the time perception parameters over should be consistent with the results obtained in prior literature.

div.head: D.4 Implementation
div.p: Algorithm 1 was implemented in the R language. The subroutine for maximum likelihood estimation (MLE) was performed with the MaxLik package (Henningsen and Toomet, 2011) and using the BFGS optimizer. BFGS perform the parameter updates using second-order information of the likelihood function and it is a standard optimizer to estimate discrete choice models (Train, 2009).

div.head: Appendix E Simulations
div.p: To analyze the consistency of our estimation procedure, we generated synthetic choice data and then attempted to recover the ground truth parameters of the utility function. In line with our experimental design, a total of 576 choice responses were generated from 72 synthetic participants across eight decision scenarios. A random perturbation with extreme value distribution was added to the deterministic component of the utility function with the goal of introducing randomness into the data-generating process and of generating choice probabilities consistent with the logit model. The influence of time perception is modeled with Stevens' power law, namely, an exponential transformation of the time attributes.

div.head: E.1 Specification of utility function
div.p: The true preference parameters are assumed to be equal to β w = −1.1, β v = −1.0, which equates to a marginal rate of substitution of waiting for in-vehicle time of 1.1. That is, participants would be willing to increase their in-vehicle time by 1.1 minutes if their waiting time decreases by one minute.

For the sake of simplicity, the scale parameters of the psychophysical functions for waiting and in-vehicle times are set to κ w = κ v = 1. In addition, the exponential parameters α w , α v of the psychophysical functions are assumed to be equal for both time attributes. This setting is consistent with the assumptions used to formulate the utility function in the numerical choices condition. Mathematically, the specification of the deterministic component of the utility function for the alternative i is the following:
div.formula: V i = β nw κ nw w α w i + β v κ v v α v i = −1 • w α i − 1.1 • v α i(51)
div.p: For the simulation, α 1 represents a scenario where perception influences decision-making. To avoid confusion, we do not refer to it as time perception because the assumptions made for simulation are consistent with the numerical condition 14 .

E.2 Scenarios S 1 : Effect of perception is known. The baseline scenario represents a situation where the shape of the psychophysical function of perception is fully known. For the sake of ease, the true data generating process (DGP) sets the exponential parameter of both time attributes to α = 1. Thus, the utility function becomes linear in parameters. Figure 10 shows the distribution of the parameters' estimates obtained over 200 Monte-Carlo simulations. The density curves are Gaussian distributions with shape parameters corresponding to the mean and standard deviation of the parameter estimates. The dashed vertical line represents the true value of the parameters associated with in-vehicle and waiting times. The plots on the left side illustrate the impact of the scale parameter of the random error λ on the estimates of the parameters of the utility function. As expected, the parameter estimates approach zero, and hence their bias increase with a higher value of λ. However, as shown in the plots on the left side, the estimates become unbiased when they are scaled by λ. With non-synthetic data, there is no access to λ, and thus, the modeler can only identify the weight between the linear parameters and λ (see discussion on identifiability, Section 4.2). λ is inversely proportional to the variance of the random error of the extreme value distribution, that is, the extent of unobservables in the utility function.
div.formula: θ w θ w λ θ v θ v
div.p: S 2 : The effect of perception is not captured. This scenario studies the impact of ignoring the effect of perception on the specification of the utility function. The influence of perception is induced by setting α = 0.9 in the specification of the utility function of the true DGP 15 . To estimate 15 In practice, any value of α close to 1 can be used for the simulation. the ground truth parameters, the utility function is intentionally misspecified by fixing α = 1. This may represent a situation in the transportation literature where a linearin-parameters utility function is wrongly assumed to capture the impact of human perception in travel decisions. Figure 11 shows the distribution of estimates of the parameters associated with the preferences for waiting and in-vehicle times. Figure 12 shows the marginal rate of substitution of waiting for in-vehicle times. In contrast to Simulation S 1 , the adjustment of the parameter estimates by the scale of the random error λ does not fully correct the bias. Regardless, the bias of the preference parameters is not transferred to the marginal rate of substitution and hence, the latter can be properly recovered. S 3 : The effect of perception is captured. In contrast to the previous scenarios, α is now defined as a free parameter. Figure 13 shows the distribution of estimates of the parameters associated with the preferences for waiting and in-vehicle times when α is jointly estimated. The plots in Figure 14 show the distribution of estimates of α and of the marginal rate of substitution of waiting for in-vehicle time. Note that the inclusion of α as a free parameter significantly increases the variance of the estimates of the preference parameter (Figure 13) compared to scenarios S 1 and S 2 . However, the parameters are now unbiased. The estimator of α has a higher variance than the estimator of the MRS and it is unbiased. Despite the increase in the variance of the parameter estimates, the marginal rate of substitution exhibits the same efficiency observed in the previous scenarios. E.3 Insights I 1 . The marginal rate of substitution (MRS) can be recovered when the influence of time perception is not captured but only if the exponents of the time attributes are the same Simulation S 1 shows that the linear weights of the utility function estimated with a logit model are confounded with the scale of the random error. A direct implication is that only the ratio between two linear weights can be recovered. This result can be proven to hold for the linearin-parameters utility function because the scale of the random error gets canceled out (Eq. 13, Section 4.2). A more interesting finding is observed in Simulation S 2 where the MRS is shown to be recovered even when the utility function is misspecified. Simulation S 3 shows the same finding. This result will not necessarily hold in a model where the exponents of the time attributes are different. I 2 . Low statistical power to capture the effect of perception in the discrete choice model.
div.formula: θ w θ w λ θ v θ v
θ w λ θ v λ θ w θ v−
div.p: The estimators of the time perception parameters indicate an increase in variance when the effect of perception is captured in the discrete choice model. This can lead to confidence intervals with higher coverages and hence a lower rejection of the null hypotheses. Possible remedies to increase statistical power are to increase the sample size or to limit the degrees of freedom of the model by combining choice data from multiple experimental conditions. A different choice of the attributes' values set in the decision scenarios can also contribute to better identification of the exponential parameter of the time attributes. I 3 . Bias-variance trade-off in models that captures the effect of perception.

Simulation S 3 shows that the joint estimation of the effect of time perception and the preference parameters results in estimators with a high variance but no biased. Simulation S 2 shows that ignoring the effect of time perception results in biased estimators but with low variance. Hence, if the sample size or the effect of time perception is small, hypothesis testing may become more reliable when time perception is not captured. The reason is that the reduction in the variance of the estimators could compensate for a small increase in bias. In contrast, with a larger sample size, it may be convenient to estimate the effect of time perception in the model.

body.note: Since the Benjamini-Hochberg procedure is less conservative than the Bonferroni correction, the former also rejects both null hypotheses
Since only waiting and in-vehicle times vary across bus routes, walking time is excluded from the analysis

Under the presence of real waiting time information, some travelers experiencing long waiting may have shifted to alternative routes with the goal of reducing waiting time. Then, the difference in perceived waiting time reported in the on-site surveys could have been mainly attributed to self-selection effects. Therefore, the authors' interpretation of the effect of displaying waiting time information on perceived waiting should be considered cautiously.
This follows from Assumption A 4 , Appendix C and the fact that the two attributes are presented with stimulus of the same modality and intensity

The difference in lower bound does not imply that an attribute is necessarily higher than the other, but it supports an inverse relationship between the average time estimates and the exponent of a time attribute.
This estimation strategy was helpful to account for the heterogeneity of preferences without capturing it explicitly in the model specifica-
tion. Besides, it allowed us to assess if the conclusions drawn from the hypotheses tests are robust across cities.

In the numerical choices condition, both attributes are presented with stimuli of the same modality and with the same intensity. Hence, assuming the same exponential parameters is reasonable (Assumption A N1 , Appendix C).

div.p: The Python code that implements the computer experiment is available at https://github.com/pabloguarda/ route-choice-experiment. The participants' choice data and the R code that reproduces all the analyses of this paper are available at https://github.com/pabloguarda/ perceived-route-choice.
